messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba on Jim Gilbert's webpage
messages.msgSnippet: Jim and all, Thanks for the feedback. It s highly appreciated..:) Regards Fredrik
messages.messageBody:
Jim and all,

Thanks for the feedback. It's highly appreciated..:)

Regards
Fredrik


Jim Gilbert wrote:

>Fredrik and all,
>
>I agree with the earlier posts.
>
>The one I have is strange because the seppa dai, kozuka ana and sukashi carving are very much like Kyo sukashi, but the thickness and folding are like a Ko-Tosho guard. Ita plate tsuba with extensive sukashi work are usually attributed to Katchushi, and that's why I placed the guard on that page. The iron is more like Owari than any of the above, though. It's a strange combination, but each "component" is consistent with ca. late Muromachi.
>
>Your guard has a wider seppa dai, wider kozuka ana, thicker sukashi walls and a thicker plate. It has a lot of rust and pitting that make it hard to see the surface but the unrusted areas look very flat and sharp. Nothing about it points to an early origin, despite using the same design. Without seeing it in person it's hard to say if it is a modern repro that has been intentionally rusted or an Edo period guard in poor condition. I wouldn't be surprised if it's modern. Thanks for posting your tsuba and thanks for the great responses.
>
>Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba on Jim Gilbert's webpage
messages.msgSnippet: ... No, I did mean late 20th century.  The red crusty rust on relatively clean metal bespeaks something tarted up to be what its not. Barry Thomas.
messages.messageBody:
Curran wrote:

> I think he meant late 19th century (post 1870),
> but I could be wrong.

No, I did mean late 20th century. The red crusty rust on relatively clean metal
bespeaks something tarted up to be what its not.

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba on Jim Gilbert's webpage
messages.msgSnippet: Milt mentioning Sasano made me think of an example from the NTHK shinsa in London.  Not talking about copies or junk, there was an early guard with the classic
messages.messageBody:
Milt mentioning Sasano made me think of an example from the NTHK shinsa in London. Not talking about copies or junk, there was an early guard with the classic kiri mon and karakusa motif often seen in Kyo-sukashi tsuba. Just like number 37 in Sasano's Early Japanese Sword Guards. If I was looking at a photo I would have no problem calling it Kyo sukashi. The "problem" is that the rim was a mass of Owari-style tekkotsu. It's easier to change sukashi design than to change ore/processing/forging so the kantei went to Owari rather than Kyo. Kantei from photos is risky.

Jim



to illustrate the point raised about later " copies "............

please klick ...........

http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=3782213098

and then compare with the FINE example in Sasano's sukashi book,page
56, tsuba # 20.

Same design but MAJOR difference in all respects.

milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba on Jim Gilbert's webpage
messages.msgSnippet: Fredrik and all, I agree with the earlier posts. The one I have is strange because the seppa dai, kozuka ana and sukashi carving are very much like Kyo
messages.messageBody:
Fredrik and all,

I agree with the earlier posts.

The one I have is strange because the seppa dai, kozuka ana and sukashi carving are very much like Kyo sukashi, but the thickness and folding are like a Ko-Tosho guard. Ita plate tsuba with extensive sukashi work are usually attributed to Katchushi, and that's why I placed the guard on that page. The iron is more like Owari than any of the above, though. It's a strange combination, but each "component" is consistent with ca. late Muromachi.

Your guard has a wider seppa dai, wider kozuka ana, thicker sukashi walls and a thicker plate. It has a lot of rust and pitting that make it hard to see the surface but the unrusted areas look very flat and sharp. Nothing about it points to an early origin, despite using the same design. Without seeing it in person it's hard to say if it is a modern repro that has been intentionally rusted or an Edo period guard in poor condition. I wouldn't be surprised if it's modern. Thanks for posting your tsuba and thanks for the great responses.

Jim



Hi all,
This post is mainly directed to Mr Gilbert but I thought that maybe if
someone else would like to comment that would be great.
I was browsing your lovely tsuba site and have a question regarding the
last tsuba on page two of the Early Iron tsuba link.
http://home.earthlink.net/%7Ejggilbert/oldiron2.htm
You are writing that it's an unusual guard, does this mean its hard to
kantei? How confident are you about it being a late Muromachi tsuba?
Have you or someone else seen this type of tsuba before, maybe in books
as for reference?
The thing is that I have a very similar tsuba, almost identical, and i
would like to have as much information about it as possible. Do you
think it may be from the same era as yours or would mine be a later copy?
The measurements on my tsuba are almost the same as yours, mine is
slightly thicker.
8.0 cm H x 8.0 cm W x 0.4 cm T

Please take a look at it on
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tsuba1.htm

Regards
Fredrik



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Tsuba on Jim Gilbert's webpage
messages.msgSnippet: Maybe my imagination, but to my eye many of these late copies (how late remains to be seen I guess) have a look of a stamped out piece of metal; literally
messages.messageBody:
Maybe my imagination, but to my eye many of these
"late" copies (how late remains to be seen I guess)
have a look of a stamped out piece of metal; literally
the design and "flatness" of the metal looks like
it was done with a stamping machine. I'm purely
guessing, but could it be these are modern iai
tsuba that have been "aged" in a bucket of acid
over night (or maybe a little longer)?

Rich S
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba on Jim Gilbert's webpage
messages.msgSnippet: Fredrik, I think he meant late 19th century (post 1870), but I could be wrong. Designs re-occur with little change over a much longer period of time than I
messages.messageBody:
Fredrik,

I think he meant late 19th century (post 1870), but I
could be wrong.

Designs re-occur with little change over a much longer
period of time than I would have thought when I first
started in this hobby. In this case, we are comparing
a 16th century tsuba to a 19th century one. The
workmanship and material is different, but the design
is the same.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba on Jim Gilbert's webpage
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Blokes, I love opening my mouth so others can put their feet in... I await correction, but I think Fredrik s tsuba is a very late copy as it (a) simply
messages.messageBody:
Dear Blokes,

I love opening my mouth so others can put their feet in...

I await correction, but I think Fredrik's tsuba is a very late copy as it (a)
simply lacks the aesthetic excellence of the original (b) its condition is
extremely poor (c) it is so "picture perfect" that I think it has been copied
from the original out of a book!!! Possibly even late 20th century...

Best regards,

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Fredrik Persson <fredmans@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, February 23, 2005 4:35 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Tsuba on Jim Gilbert's webpage



Hi all,
This post is mainly directed to Mr Gilbert but I thought that maybe if
someone else would like to comment that would be great.
I was browsing your lovely tsuba site and have a question regarding the
last tsuba on page two of the Early Iron tsuba link.
http://home.earthlink.net/%7Ejggilbert/oldiron2.htm
You are writing that it's an unusual guard, does this mean its hard to
kantei? How confident are you about it being a late Muromachi tsuba?
Have you or someone else seen this type of tsuba before, maybe in books
as for reference?
The thing is that I have a very similar tsuba, almost identical, and i
would like to have as much information about it as possible. Do you
think it may be from the same era as yours or would mine be a later copy?
The measurements on my tsuba are almost the same as yours, mine is
slightly thicker.
8.0 cm H x 8.0 cm W x 0.4 cm T

Please take a look at it on
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tsuba1.htm

Regards
Fredrik






Yahoo! Groups Links

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba on Jim Gilbert's webpage
messages.msgSnippet: Fredrik, I ll stick my neck out first. I d say same design, later copy. Possibly much later. There are several differences. For starters, the shape of the
messages.messageBody:
Fredrik,

I'll stick my neck out first.
I'd say same design, later copy. Possibly much
later. There are several differences. For starters,
the shape of the seppa dai. The quality of the iron is
also an important one and probably why Jim's is dated
as he has it. The sukashi on his is very gentle, yet
the iron like extra hard armor iron so the tsuba could
be considered either kyo-sukashi or katchushi.

In a case like yours, someone just needs to make a
judgement call on the iron and the workmanship of the
sukashi.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] FW: Paperback "Japanese Names and How to Read Them"
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA - I only waited a year because of computer troubles.  About this time last year I had PC problems and had to use my son s hand-me-down
messages.messageBody:
Jim,
HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA - I only waited a year because of computer troubles. About
this time last year I had PC problems and had to use my son's hand-me-down
computer. I fixed my regular one (long story - 12 months worth!!) and merged
all the mail files from the other computer, and simply thought that it was a
current posting!!! I didn't even look at the date, just the info...

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, February 17, 2005 2:32 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] FW: Paperback "Japanese Names and How to Read Them"



Barry,
The person who made the offer to email the acrobat file chose not post it on the
group file page. I didn't follow up with him, so I don't know why. If anyone
has a copy of the file, please post it.

You're a patient fellow to wait a year before prompting.
Jim
